method_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 220°C fan. Preheat the oven to 220°C fan then place a large baking tray into the oven. Put 250g of plain flour, a big pinch of sea salt, 1 teaspoon of thyme leaves, 85ml warm water into a large mixing bowl with 5 tablespoons of olive oil. Mix together and knead by hand to form a dough. Put the dough onto a floured surface and roll it out into a roughly 14-sized rectangle. Transfer the dough to the hot baking tray in the oven.

Make the mustard filling by mixing an egg creme fraiche into a medium mixing bowl with 1 tablespoon wholegrain mustard, 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard, 1 teaspoon runny honey, the grated zest of 1⁄2 an unwaxed lemon, 1⁄2 a teaspoon bashed fennel seeds, and 1og freshly grated Parmesan. Put to one side.

Cook the greens by removing leaves from stems of Swiss chard or spinach and finely chop the stems. Heat a frying pan over a medium heat and add some olive oil. Once hot, add the stems and cook for 2-3 minutes. Roughly chop the leaves then add these too, cooking them for 4-5 minutes until wilted and all the moisture has evaporated. Set aside to cool.

Prepare the mushrooms by using a brush or a piece of kitchen paper to remove any dirt from mixed mushrooms, then tear them into bite-sized pieces, varying the size and shape. Put the mushrooms in a bowl with 1 teaspoon of Dijon mustard and stir gently so they are all coated in the mustard.
Working quickly, spread the dough with the crème fraîche mixture, top with the wilted greens and finish with the musardy mushrooms, then grate over 50g of Parmesan.

Bake the tart for 15-18 minutes until the edges are deep golden and the filling is bubbling. Cool on the baking tray for 5 minutes, then carefully slide onto a wire rack to cool. Serve at room temperature (or hot from the oven if you like!) with a bright green salad like the one on page 20.
